Universal Design Brochure

The idea for this project was to determine what I believe to be the top 5 principles of Good Design. Whether you are a graphic designer, industrial designer or a web designer the principles would serve to be valuable regardless of the industry you are designing for.

Role

For this project I was the lead graphic designer. The idea was provided by my San Jose State University instructor, Gregory Hom. I was responsible for establishing creative direction for all designs, from low to high fidelity. I performed retouching and manipulation of images and I ensured that the project was complete on schedule with high quality and detail.

  • Role

    Graphic Designer

  • Type

    School

  • Software

    InDesign, Illustrator, PhotoShop

  • Duration

    Nov 2020 â€“ Dec 2020

Goals

Come up with 5 principles that would act as an umbrella for every design field within the design industry; a universal code of things to consider as a designer in the industry.

Good graphic design is more than just the fundamentals and a major goal was to integrate them without broadcasting them to the viewer.

Challenges

How to consolidate the many aspects of good design into five high level principles and developing a visually interesting and informative way of represent five principles of good design in a printed format.

Approach

When determining my 5 principles there were two values of design that I kept coming back to:
1. Honest.
2.Easy to understand.

Whether it is service, product, or simply a poster good design does not try to be anything that it is not, it is universally true to the user(s). I loved the word universal and decided to make the theme of my brochure. When it came to color, imagery and typography I took inspiration from the International Typographic Style of the 1950s.

My Learnings

Themes and identity are important. Having a type scale, color system and imagery that comes together as one will help tell a visual story. Consistency in my designs kept readers engaged. Spread compositions and familiar visual elements helped represent the theme and identity, but also guided the reader from spread to spread without getting lost. Research is key, I am not the first to be put to this challenge and definitely not the last, there are so many articles and content on what makes good design. Find something or someone who inspires you.
